instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touch Bar not powering on
threads.message:
Device came in liquid damaged and had missing R701 to CPUVIN and RA603 to <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_GFXIMVP_VIN</SIGNAL>. Replaced and device boots up normally now. Performed a QC test and gave USC. Everything was working normally with board loosely installed. After screwing down logic board screws to frame, The touchbar stopped working. Unscrewed logicboard screw next to Left Hall Sensor and touchbar came back. Was unable to find anything grounding out board, so I assumed Left Hall sensor was bad. Replaced and still had the same issue.

Installed board into a known good topcase with a different touch bar and still had the same issue.

When I boot the board with the original topcase, touchbar is no longer working at all now. Tried booting into safe mode and a USB test os and still had the same issues.

Measured voltage on J4401 and J4402 and getting 1.8 on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0SW_DFR</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_RESET_L</SIGNAL>. Seems like device is getting proper power but perhaps a data line is missing?

Pull up resistors for <SIGNAL>DFRDRV_I2C_SDA</SIGNAL> <RESISTOR>R3918</RESISTOR> and <SIGNAL>DFRDRV_I2C_SCL</SIGNAL> <RESISTOR>R3917</RESISTOR> both measuring proper resistance of 4.7k ohms
Pull up resistors for <SIGNAL>DFR_TOUCH_ROM_I2C_SDA</SIGNAL> <RESISTOR>R3916</RESISTOR> and <SIGNAL>DFR_TOUCH_ROM_I2C_SCL</SIGNAL> <RESISTOR>R3917</RESISTOR> measuring 2.2k ohms

Getting 0V on <SIGNAL>DFR_TOUCH_LID</SIGNAL>, which from my understanding is suppose to be 0V when <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.42v on <TRANSISTOR>Q4400</TRANSISTOR>

Not quite sure where to go from here. Thank you in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touch Bar not powering on
threads.message: I forgot to mention that when lid is closed, MacBook kernal panics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touch Bar not powering on
threads.message:
Check for knocked off components, or broken traces.
Possibly to have more areas affected by corrosion, or crap underneath some BGA chip (<CHIP>U3900</CHIP>?)...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touch Bar not powering on
threads.message: Wasn't able to find any missing components, but everything keeps circling back to <CHIP>U3900</CHIP>. The only thing is that I do not have a stencil for this IC at the moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touch Bar not powering on
threads.message:
Heat it with good flux.
Just to burn eventually crap, no more than 180-200 degrees; no need to melt the balls.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touch Bar not powering on
threads.message: Will that be safe even though the IC is underfilled?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touch Bar not powering on
threads.message: Oops, if is completely underfilled doesn't help maybe...
